Graphical abstract This review summarizes current research progress and future development opportunities of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures as functional sulfur catalysts for lithium–sulfur batteries. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have attracted wide attention for their high theoretical energy density, low cost, and environmental friendliness. However, the shuttle effect of polysulfides and the insulation of active materials severely restrict the development of Li-S batteries. Constructing conductive sulfur scaffolds with catalytic conversion capability for cathodes is an efficient approach to solving above issues. Vanadium-based compounds and their heterostructures have recently emerged as functional sulfur catalysts supported on conductive scaffolds. These compounds interact with polysulfides via different mechanisms to alleviate the shuttle effect and accelerate the redox kinetics, leading to higher Coulombic efficiency and enhanced sulfur utilization. Reports on vanadium-based nanomaterials in Li-S batteries have been steadily increasing over the past several years. In this review, first, we provide an overview of the synthesis of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures. Then, we discuss the interactions and constitutive relationships between vanadium-based catalysts and polysulfides formed at sulfur cathodes. We summarize the mechanisms that contribute to the enhancement of electrochemical performance for various types of vanadium-based catalysts, thus providing insights for the rational design of sulfur catalysts. Finally, we offer a perspective on the future directions for the research and development of vanadium-based sulfur catalysts. Keywords Vanadium-based compound Vanadium-based heterostructure Lithium–sulfur battery Sulfur catalyst Polysulfide regulation 1 Introduction Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are the most sustainable option for energy storage among the batteries that are currently available [1–3]. Ni and Co are typically used as electrode materials in these batteries [4–6]. However, a recent study reported that Europe may face Ni and Co scarcity by 2030. Hence, automobile manufacturers and energy providers are pursuing alternative technologies with a higher capacity and lower demand for essential mineral resources owing to the shortage of fossil fuels [7]. Lithium–sulfur batteries, which are considered as the holy grail of power storage systems, possess a high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mA h g−1) that is five times greater than that of commercially available LIBs (∼300 mA h g−1) [8,9]. In contrast to the limited availability of Ni and Co, sulfur, which is the tenth most abundant element on earth, can be acquired from the byproducts of industrial processes such as petroleum refining. The emergence of low-cost, eco-friendly Li–S batteries promotes their application as sustainable energy sources [10–12]. However, Li–S batteries are not infallible because of the shuttle effect and sluggish reaction kinetics, thus limiting their commercialization [13,14]. The shuttle effect refers to the intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) dissolved in the electrolyte during cycling processes and diffused through the separator to the anode [15,16]. The interconversion of solid–liquid and solid–solid phase during the charge/discharge exhibits slow redox reaction rate and limits the kinetics of the total reaction. The liquid polysulfides react directly with the lithium anode, which eventually causes irreversible loss of active materials, decay of battery life, and low Coulombic efficiency [17]. In addition, elemental sulfur and its discharge products have low electrical conductivity at room temperature, making electron transport difficult. The density variation between sulfur and Li2S causes volume fluctuations in the electrode during galvanostatic charge/discharge, thereby destroying their internal structure [18,19]. Studies have been conducted to overcome these limitations to realize high-performance Li–S batteries [20,21]. Currently, the main methods include designing cathode scaffolds [22,23], modifying the lithium anode [24–26], adding functional interlayers [27], and optimizing the electrode binders [28–30]. The sulfur cathode predominantly determines the electrochemical properties of the battery [31,32]. Hence, functional catalysts on conductive frameworks have been designed as sulfur scaffolds to restrict the shuttling of LiPSs by physical confinement and polar chemisorption, and to accelerate the redox reaction rate [33–37]. Vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures with tailorable valence and compositions compared with Fe-/Ni-/Co-based compounds have emerged as a solution for this issue in recent years (Fig. 1 ) [38–41]. The multiple valence (from 0 to +5) facilitates partial electroneutrality and thus optimizes the polysulfide conversion process for higher reversible capacity and more stable rate performance [42–47]. Vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures usually enhance the electrochemical capabilities of Li–S batteries via four approaches: (1) physical confinement, (2) polar–polar interactions, (3) Lewis acid–base interactions, and (4) thiosulfate interactions [48–50]. Physical confinement involves micromorphological design with porous, shelled or layered structures, which is a common strategy to store polysulfides at the cathode and effectively limit the shuttle effect [51,52]. Polar metal compounds can anchor polysulfides through polar–polar interactions owing to their asymmetric nature [53]. Lewis bases that possess lone electron pairs interact with Lewis acids that have unoccupied orbitals to form metal–S coordinate bonds, thus preventing the loss of polysulfides [54–56]. Thiosulfate interactions are typically observed in metal compounds with high redox potentials [57–59]. Long-chain polysulfides undergo two reduction steps to form thiosulfate/polythionate species and short-chain polysulfides, which accelerates the reaction rate while impeding the dissolution of polysulfides [60]. Furthermore, heterostructures have been demonstrated to effectively modify the deficiencies of the redox process through synergistic reinforcement of the dual phases [61,62]. The rich valence states and varied crystal structures of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures provide diverse electrochemical properties, thereby accelerating the improvement and commercialization of functional cathode scaffolds for Li–S batteries [63]. Reports on vanadium-based nanomaterials in Li–S batteries have been steadily increasing over the past several years. In this review, we provide a detailed overview of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures as Li–S battery cathode catalysts from aspects of mechanism, synthesis, and structure–performance relationships, and offer insightful perspectives on the future research and development directions. 2 Fundamental electrochemistry of Li–S batteries The typical structure of a Li–S battery is shown in Fig. 2 (a). The internal composition of a Li–S battery mainly consists of an elemental sulfur cathode, a lithium metal anode, a separator, and an organic electrolyte. The basic electrochemical mechanism of Li–S batteries is the interconversion of sulfur and sulfur-related species in Fig. 2(b). Elemental sulfur interacts with lithium ions during the discharge process and gradually converts to Li2S (Eqs. (1) and (2)). (1) C a t h o d e : S 8 + 16 L i + + 16 e - → 8 L i 2 S (2) A n o d e : L i → L i + + e - According to the phase transition between sulfur and sulfur-related species, the discharge reaction can be divided into four stages. Stage I: Solid-phase orthorhombic sulfur transforms to liquid-phase high-order Li2S x (6 ≤ x ≤ 8) through the opening of the ring structure, according to Eqs. (3) and (4). (3) S 8 + 2 L i + + 2 e - → L i 2 S 8 (4) 3 L i 2 S 8 + 2 L i + + 2 e - → 4 L i 2 S 6 Stage II: As more lithium ions are added to the reaction process, low-order Li2S4 is obtained by the liquid–liquid transition, according to Eq. (5). (5) 2 L i 2 S 6 + 2 L i + + 2 e - → 3 L i 2 S 4 The above two stages jointly provide a quarter of the total theoretical specific capacity (419 mA h g−1), which is equivalent to accepting 0.5 electrons per sulfur atom. Stage III: The liquid-phase Li2S4 is further reduced and converted to solid-phase Li2S2. This stage involves the liquid–solid conversion in Eq. (6), leading to a gradual decrease in redox kinetics. (6) L i 2 S 4 + 2 L i + + 2 e - → 2 L i 2 S 2 Stage IV: The last stage is the further reduction from Li2S2 to Li2S, which can be seen in Eq. (7). Due to the solid–solid transition reaction, the high degree of polarization makes the reaction kinetics slow. (7) L i 2 S 2 + 2 L i + + 2 e - → 2 L i 2 S Stage III and IV provide three-quarters of the total theoretical specific capacity (1256 mA h g−1), which is equivalent to accepting 1.5 electrons per sulfur atom. During charging, Li2S decomposes into lithium ions and sulfur. However, the sulfur evolution reaction is hindered by the high activation energy required to dissociate Li2S, which leads to a high amount of 'dead' sulfur. Vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures have been reported to facilitate the interconversion between S8 and Li2S, which enhances reversibility of electrochemical reactions in Li–S batteries. 3 Preparation of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures The current preparation methods for vanadium-based cathode catalysts are energy-efficient and inexpensive to meet the requirements of industrial applications [65–67]. The main preparation methods for vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures include (1) physical preparation method, (2) hydrothermal method, (3) heat treatment method, (4) chemical vapor deposition (CVD), and (5) template method. Physical preparation technique involves mechanical stripping or grinding of precursor materials, resulting in high-purity products while minimizing contamination. For example, lamellar V2O5 can be obtained through rapid gas-assisted exfoliation [68]. Hydrothermal synthesis is a promising strategy for most vanadium oxides (e.g., VO2 and V2O3), leading to homogeneous particle size, perfect crystal shapes, and well-dispersed materials without requiring high-temperature treatment [69–72]. Vanadium oxides are obtained through simple physical preparation and hydrothermal methods. One-pot hydrothermal synthesis can also be used to obtain vanadium sulfides from Na3VO4 and thioacetamide (TAA) [73,74]. The heat treatment method is simple, sustainable, and scalable; it directly obtains complex structural molecules without intermediate separation by including multi-step reactions in one procedure. This method is highly yielded, inexpensive, and suitable for industrial applications [75]. Generally, vanadium nitrides with diverse microstructures can be obtained through the pretreatment of vanadium oxides and subsequent heat treatment under NH3 atmosphere. [76,77]. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) is another common bottom-up preparation technique. In this process, precursors react at relatively high temperatures and are deposited on substrates to obtain monolayer or multilayer nanomaterials [78,79]. A novel approach for synthesizing nanostructured materials is the template method, which uses a nanoporous metal organic framework (e.g. MIL-47) as a matrix for the synthesis of vanadium-based compounds, exhibiting adjustable pore sizes, large specific surface area, and framework structural diversity. Fabrication of vanadium-based heterostructures usually involves a multi-step process. For instance, oxide–carbide heterostructures can be prepared using MIL-47 as precursors or through hydrothermal treatment of pre-prepared carbides [80,81]. Oxide–nitride materials are usually produced via pretreatment to produce vanadium oxides followed by thermal nitridation [82]. By utilizing electrostatic spinning technology during the preparation process of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures, desirable physical morphologies and chemical compositions are generated [83]. Table 1 summarizes recent advances in the preparation methods and their influence on resulting morphologies of vanadium-based heterostructures. 4 Vanadium-based compounds as functional catalysts for Li–S battery cathodes Vanadium-based compounds are generally considered suitable sulfur cathode catalysts for their robust polar–polar interactions with polysulfides [109]. Additionally, they can be used as redox mediators to facilitate the conversion of soluble LiPSs to insoluble Li2S2 and Li2S, thereby accelerating the reaction kinetics [110]. This section will discuss different types of vanadium compounds (oxides, nitrides, sulfides, carbide, and other kinds) used in Li–S battery cathodes and their corresponding electrochemical behaviors. 4.1 Vanadium oxides Vanadium oxides are strongly polarized and can anchor polysulfides via robust polar–polar interactions, thereby astricting the polysulfide shuttle effect at the sulfur cathode [111–115]. They participate in the ‘Wackenroder reaction’, in which VO2 and V2O5 react with polysulfides to form thiosulfate/polythionate species and reduce the charge transfer resistance in the electrochemical processes at the electrode, accelerating the slow reaction kinetics [116,117]. Wang et al. proposed a three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical structure of paramontroseite VO2 [VO2(P)] on nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNT) as the catalytic scaffold for sulfur cathodes [71]. VO2(P) exhibited excellent conductivity at room temperature owing to its unique structure. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), VO2(P) nanoparticles were deposited uniformly on the NCNT layer using a simple hydrothermal method. Because the redox potential window of VO2(P) overtopped that of polysulfides, the long-chain polysulfides were oxidized to thiosulfates on the particle surface. Subsequently, the thiosulfates generated polythionates and short-chain polysulfides [118]. The comparison of pristine VO2(P) and Li2S4-treated VO2(P) via X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) and electron energy-loss spectra (EELS) confirmed a valence shift of vanadium from + 4 to + 3 in Fig. 3(b). Similarly, the sulfur K-edge curves confirmed the presence of thiosulfates. Such unconventional reaction pathways not only anchored polysulfides robustly via intermolecular force but also mediated the interconversion of sulfur-related species. Additionally, the polythionates formed through the two-step reactions were insoluble in the electrolyte, inhibiting the shuttle effect of polysulfides. The VO2(P)-NCNT/S cathode exhibited excellent performance at the high sulfur loading. The areal capacity exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 10.2 mA h cm−2 at 0.2 C. Wang et al. designed ultra-thin 2D V2O5 nanosheets as the catalyst for polysulfides via rapid gas-assisted exfoliation in Fig. 3(c) [68]. This efficient and non-toxic synthesis approach, without the insertion of extra contaminants during the exfoliation process, resulted in extremely clean nanosheets. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) and the corresponding 3D images showed that the V2O5 nanosheets did not exceed seven atomic layers in Fig. 3(d). V2O5 nanosheets possessed strong surface polarity for the chemisorption of polysulfides and a redox potential of up to 3.0 V [117,119]. The V2O5/S composite cathodes showed an initial discharge capacity of 932.8 mA h g−1 with a high Coulombic efficiency of 97% and exhibited a capacity retention of 76.5% even after 150 cycles at 0.5 C. A novel V2O3-graphene hybrid synthesized via plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) was also reported as the sulfur scaffold with smooth adsorption-diffusion-conversion of polysulfides in Fig. 3(e) [72]. In addition, VO can promote the transformation of polysulfides through Lewis acid–base interactions [88]. The vacant d-orbitals of VO phase can serve as Lewis acids to bind polysulfides via the formation of V–S bonds. VO-based carbon nanofiber (VO-CNFs) fabricated by electrostatic spinning and in-situ carbothermal reduction reactions improved the reaction kinetics at the cathode in Fig. 3(f) [84]. Despite their excellent capability to adsorb and combine polysulfides, vanadium oxides cannot diffuse and transform polysulfides completely. The low electrical conductivity and strong anchoring capacity of vanadium oxides increased the potential barriers of Li+ diffusion and Li2S decomposition, which further caused difficulties in the conversion of sulfur-related substances and sluggish reaction kinetics. Therefore, novel vanadium oxide materials with suitable adsorption capacity and conductive framework should be developed as effective host materials for sulfur cathodes. 4.2 Vanadium nitrides Vanadium nitrides (VN) have good electrical conductivity (∼106 S m−1) and catalytic abilities [120]. Nitrogen atoms with their lone-electron pair can serve as conductive Lewis bases. Hence, VN can restrict LiPSs through Lewis acid–base interactions, thus minimizing the loss of the active substance [121]. Zhong et al. combined vanadium nitride arrays with porous carbon fibers (PCF/VN) and demonstrated that VN could confine sulfur in Li–S battery cathodes effectively [92]. PCF/VN was prepared by combining simple chemical etching and a solvothermal supercritical fluid approach. The integrated conductive framework of PCF/VN overcame the issue of sulfur insulation and facilitated rapid electron and ion transport in Fig. 4 (a and b). Furthermore, the Lewis acid–base interaction between VN and polysulfides allowed the active substance to be rapidly converted at the cathode, accelerating the reaction process [122]. PCF/VN showed a dual effect of physical impediment and chemical immobilization of polysulfides in Li–S batteries. The PCF/VN/S cathode exhibited excellent initial specific capacity (1310.8 mA h g−1 at 0.1C), good cycling stability (80.3% capacity retention rate after 250 cycles), and low polarization with a 0.15 V voltage gap in Fig. 4(c and d). Yang et al. reported a porous graphitic carbon with bound VN nanocrystals (3D VN@N-PGC) via a simple and scalable one-step heat treatment approach, also confirming the excellent electrocatalytic ability of VN with sulfur-based materials [75]. The co-catalytic effect of the doped N atoms and VN nanocrystals expedited the conversion of long-chain polysulfides to short-chain polysulfides and enhanced redox kinetics [123]. Ma et al. reported porous-shell VN nanobubbles (VN-NBs) for Li–S battery cathodes in Fig. 4(e), which achieved a high sulfur loading and rapid redox kinetics [93]. Porous-shell structures are capable of buffering volume expansion during sulfur lithiation and Li2S decomposition. Fig. 4(f) shows the particle size of VN-NBs as ∼500 nm obtained by organometallic compound conversion and subsequent thermal nitridation. At a sulfur loading of up to 6.8 mg cm−2, the VN-NBs/S cathodes exhibited an initial specific capacity of 798 mA h g−1 and a corresponding areal capacity of 5.43 mA h cm−2. Even though VNs featuring various microstructures act as effective catalytic materials for active sulfur species, the strong polar chemisorption between VNs and LiPSs limits the conversion of sulfur-related species during charging, thus impacting the overall reaction kinetics. In addition, most VNs are prepared at high temperatures using corrosive NH3 or nitrogen-containing reagents as the nitrogen source, which presents a potential environmental hazard [124]. 4.3 Vanadium sulfides Vanadium sulfides such as VS2, VS4, and V5S8 are appropriate functional scaffolds for sulfur cathodes owing to their desirable electrocatalytic ability, energy band positions, and exposed active sites compared with vanadium oxides [125]. Vanadium sulfides typically possess a redox voltage below 1.5 V, which helps to avoid side reactions within the operating voltage window [126,127]. According to first-principles calculations, VS2 exhibits suitable ability to anchor LiPSs, facile Li2S decomposition ability, and rapid Li+ diffusion with a low diffusion barrier [128]. Cheng et al. fabricated polar VS2 attached to a 2D layered graphene (rGO-VS2) to mitigate volume fluctuations and promote redox kinetics [95]. The layered rGO-VS2 was synthesized via a facile hydrothermal method combining graphene oxide, sodium metavanadate, and thioacetamide in Fig. 5 (a). Layered structures provide ample space for sulfur storage and effectively mitigate volume fluctuations during electrochemical processes. The rGO-VS2/S cathodes constructed using rGO-VS2 with 89% sulfur loading and without extra additives exhibited a high tap density of 1.84 g cm−3 [129,130], achieving a high-volume energy density of 1182.1 mA h cm−3 at 0.1 C. Zhu et al. obtained conjugated synthetic VS2/reduced graphene oxide nanosheets (G-VS2) using an in-situ self-assembly method in Fig. 5(b and c) [96]. G-VS2 inhibited the diffusion of polysulfides to the anode, promoted charge delivery, and buffered the volume fluctuations via a synergistic effect of physical constraint and chemical anchoring. Inspired by the catalytic effect of layered VS2 on polysulfides, Zhang et al. synthesized V5S8 nanoflakes as promoters for sulfur cathodes by intercalating V atoms between VS2 monolayers in Fig. 5(d) [97]. V5S8 nanoflakes with asymmetric spatial structures suppressed the polysulfide shuttle effect by polar–polar intermolecular forces. The embedded V atoms facilitated Li+ diffusion and electron transport and enhanced reversible charge and discharge performance as shown in Fig. 5(e). Unlike lamellar VS2, VS4 typically exhibits a horizontal quasi-1D chain structure. Luo et al. recently reported a novel 3D structure based on VS4 and reduced graphene oxide (VS4@RGO) as the sulfur scaffold [98]. VS4@RGO, obtained by the in-situ self-assembly approach, was bonded to the adjacent V4+(S2 2–)2 chains through weak van der Waals forces and achieved strong polysulfide anchoring [131,132]. The corresponding oxidation and reduction peaks of the symmetric cell revealed that VS4@RGO significantly promoted the reversible conversion of polysulfides and accelerated the reaction kinetics. In-situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained for VS4@RGO to observe the practical effects of VS4 during the electrochemical process in Fig. 5(f). The peak intensity of polysulfides in the VS4@RGO batteries was lower than that in the control sample at the discharge stage because of the fast conversion of liquid-phase sulfur-related species. Cubic Li2S appeared at the beginning of stage B. It indicated the initiation of solid-phase nucleation and clearly explained the small voltage drop at the second discharge platform. This showed that VS4 dramatically enhanced the anchoring ability and reaction reversibility of polysulfides. Even after 50 cycles, the assembled pouch cells (200 mg of active substance in each cathode) demonstrated favorable cyclability, with a reversible discharge capacity of 146 mA h. Wang et al. designed a unique walnut-shaped VS4 and combined it with carbon nanotubes to provide a high surface area and excellent electrical conductivity for high-loading Li−S batteries [99]. Although vanadium sulfides can simultaneously adsorb and catalyze polysulfides, the mechanism of charge and discharge reactions remains unclear. The complex catalytic mechanisms of metal sulfides for polysulfides in the redox process urgently need to be investigated. 4.4 Vanadium carbides Vanadium carbides enhance the charge/discharge capacity of Li–S batteries owing to their excellent electrocatalytic activity and electrical conductivity. VC possesses the highest electrical conductivity (1.6 × 104 S cm−1) among all vanadium-based compounds and demonstrates great potential for battery applications. Wei et al. designed a uniform VC structure hybridized with nitrogen-doped carbon as an efficient sulfur catalyst to enhance the redox reaction rate during charge and discharge in Fig. 6 (a and b) [100]. VC with polar nature exhibited good adsorption capability of polysulfides through polar–polar interactions, and served as the charge-transfer thruster of polysulfides in the reaction process. The optimal binding energy of polysulfides was revealed to range from −1 to −2 eV to achieve effective adsorption without affecting subsequent diffusion. The binding energy between VC (200) and Li2S6 was calculated to be −1.00 eV, indicating that VC exhibited good adsorption capacity in Fig. 6(c). In addition, the long-range conductive network formed by the interconnection of VC and 1D fibers provided abundant active sites that can promote the nucleation and growth of Li2S. A bifunctional catalyst, V8C7/phosphorus defect-integrated carbon (VPC), was prepared using a vanadium-based MOF (MIL-47) with subsequent phosphorylation [101]. MIL-47 was prepared from VCl3 and p-phthalic acid (PTA) and was calcined at 1000 °C to obtain V8C7/carbon in Fig. 6(d). The VPC combining V8C7 particles and P defects had dual-function active centers, which alleviated polysulfide shuttling and improved electron mobility in Fig. 6(e). As shown in Fig. 6(f), VPC increased the deposition of Li2S (227.9 mA h gs –1) and accelerated the redox kinetics of polysulfides. Additionally, VPC exhibited excellent Li2S solubilization capacity during Li2S dissociation (301.7 mA h gs –1), indicating that the solid–liquid phase polysulfide conversion was promoted during the charge process in Fig. 6(g). The VPC electrodes exhibited excellent electrochemical capabilities at different rates (0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C) owing to the enhanced redox reaction rate in Fig. 6(h) and decreased polarization (164 mV) between the charge and discharge platforms. However, compared to other vanadium-based compounds, vanadium carbides are less capable of regulating the dissolution of polysulfides. 4.5 Other vanadium-based compounds Along with the commonly discussed oxides, nitrides, sulfides, and carbides, there are still some other vanadium-based compounds, such as VSe2, V2CN, and single-atom materials, that have been applied for Li−S batteries in various forms. Ci et al. designed a defective vanadium diselenide with vertical graphene on carbon cloth (VSe2-VG@CC) as the electrocatalyst to convert polysulfides [133]. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), VSe2-VG@CC was synthesized by two-step CVD with different precursors on the carbon cloth. The obtained VSe2 nanosheets were dispersed on the vertical graphene layer in Fig. 7(b). DFT calculations revealed that vacancy defects in VSe2 enhanced the binding energy between VSe2-VG@CC and polysulfides, and effectively induced the deposition of Li2S on the surface [134]. In addition, the electrochemical mechanism of VSe2-VG@CC during the discharge and charge process was probed by in-situ Raman and XRD in Fig. 7(c–e). It was observed that the characteristic peak of VS2 gradually increased with the discharge process and decreased during the charge process. In the discharge stage, VSe2 with vacancies interacted with polysulfides and was partially sulfated to VS2. The affinity between atomic S and low-valent metal compounds in a polysulfide-rich environment enhanced the anchoring ability of polysulfides [135]. The electrochemical driving force during charge allowed the conversion of VS2 into VSe2, which accelerated the conversion of sulfur-related species and catalyzed the dissociation of Li2S. This work systematically explored the possible phase evolution of VSe2 with sufficient vacancies in polysulfide-rich electrochemical processes through in-situ characterizations, leading to novel insights for defect engineering in Li−S batteries. Cheong et al. constructed a straightforward and scalable synthesis approach for vanadium carbonitride (V2CN/C) with a high specific surface area [136]. In contrast to the conventional NH3 nitridation and high-temperature carbon thermal reduction, V2CN/C was prepared by a simple one-step thermal treatment of the metal precursor and graphitic carbon nitride mixture under argon gas. V2CN/C could anchor asymmetrical polysulfides through polar–polar interactions and reduce the dissolution rate of active materials at the cathode. According to the DFT calculation, V2CN exhibited decent adsorption capacity for polysulfides. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves and corresponding Tafel slopes showed that V2CN/C possessed the best oxidation capacity from Li2S to LiPSs in Fig. 7(f and g). The cell with the V2CN/C interlayer exhibited an excellent peak specific capacity (941 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C) and good cycling stability (89% capacity retention after 300 cycles) at the high sulfur loading of 4.5 mg cm−2. This study provided a facile approach to synthesize highly dispersed nitride, carbonitride and carbide nanoparticles on 3D carbon scaffolds. For a more comprehensive and visual comparison, Table 2 summarizes the largest capacity and other relevant electrochemical parameters of various vanadium-based compounds applied for Li-S battery cathodes. Introducing single-atom catalysts to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries also has received considerable attention in exploring practical applications [137]. Guided by DFT calculations, Zhou et al. designed and prepared atomic vanadium sites on graphene for sulfur cathodes [138]. Single vanadium metal atoms effectively captured soluble lithium polysulfides and significantly accelerated bidirectional reaction (sulfur reduction and Li2S oxidation), improving sulfur utilization, rate capability, and cycle life. However, cycling stability and metal-loading are the major challenges for single-atom catalysts. 5 Vanadium-based heterostructures as functional catalysts for Li-S battery cathodes Accomplishing multiple functions using single components as the catalyst for Li-S battery cathodes is challenging. In contrast, the rational selection of two or more compounds to form heterogeneous materials with versatile properties can fulfill multiple requirements for high-performance Li-S batteries [139]. In this section, we will summarize recent advances of vanadium-based heterostructures as favorable sulfur catalysts in Li-S batteries [140]. 5.1 Vanadium-based oxide–carbide heterostructures Cai et al. constructed a bifunctional V8C7-VO2 heterogeneous nanoflower using 3D printing technology (3DP) as a polysulfide immobilizer and lithium stabilizer in Li–S batteries [102]. A V8C7-VO2/S ink derived from the sulfur-amine route was employed as the cathode; meanwhile the lithiophilic V8C7-VO2 could be used as a lithium dendrite inhibitor to induce uniform nucleation of lithium and stabilize the lithium anode in Fig. 8 (a). The interface between V8C7 and VO2 in the heterostructure was clearly identified by high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image in Fig. 8(b). Two characteristic X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) peaks in the high-resolution V 2p spectrum at 513.3 and 521.0 eV were assigned to V8C7 (V δ+, 0 < δ < 3) and VO2 (V4+), respectively in Fig. 8(c). The Li–S battery assembled with bifunctional 3DP-V8C7-VO2 exhibited good discharge specific capacity (643.5 mA h g−1 at 6.0 C) and significant potential for practical applications (7.36 mA h cm−2 with a high sulfur loading of 9.2 mg cm−2). Nguyen et al. also investigated carbon textiles furnished with VC/V2O3 − x nanoparticles as catalytic materials for sulfur cathodes and lithium anodes [103]. The VC/V2O3 − x hybrid nanoparticles on the cathode side could effectively trap polysulfides and catalyze the detachment of sulfur from polysulfides. Furthermore, VC/V2O3 − x on the anode enabled the uniform deposition of lithium and prevented the non-directional growth of lithium dendrites, allowing for long-term and stable battery operation. Zhang et al. fabricated an MIL-47-derived V2O3/V8C7 heterostructure for enhancing the regulation of polysulfides in Fig. 8(d and e), in which V2O3 contributed to strong adsorption whereas V8C7 promoted efficient catalysis [81]. Hence, this combination effectively regulated the anchoring, transfer, and conversion of polysulfides while mitigating their loss and improving the redox rate. Recent studies of vanadium-based sulfur catalysts have typically focused on regulating the behavior of polysulfides to obtain high performance Li−S batteries. However, the phase evolution of vanadium-based materials in a polysulfide-rich environment during the electrochemical reaction has been rarely mentioned. Dong et al. recently designed VC-VO heterogeneous particles supported on a hierarchical porous carbon matrix (VC-VO/HPC) to study the dynamic phase evolution and resulting performance [141]. The obtained VC-VO heterogeneous particles combined the strong adsorption ability of VO and the redox activity of VC to achieve strong anchoring, fast diffusion and efficient conversion of polysulfides simultaneously. Both in-situ Raman and XRD characterizations clearly revealed the generation of vanadium sulfides during the electrochemical process in Fig. 8(f and g). The phase evolution and the existence of intermediate products were supposed to accelerate the interconversion of liquid polysulfides, resulting in better electrochemical performances in Fig. 8(h). 5.2 Vanadium-based oxide–nitride heterostructures Song et al. fabricated a VO2-VN for sulfur cathodes to realize simultaneous immobilization-diffusion-transformation of polysulfides, which conserved battery life to the maximum degree in Fig. 9 (a) [82]. The binary host, combining VO2 (strong anchoring) and VN (fast electron transport), alleviated the shuttle effect and boosted the redox reaction. The clear interface between VO2 and VN facilitated charge transfer and conversion of sulfur-related species in Fig. 9(b and c). Therefore, the obtained sulfur cathode exhibited good initial specific capacity (935 mA h g−1) and long cycle stability at 2 C (low decay of 0.06% per cycle) in Fig. 9(d). Recently, a flexible 3D N-doped graphene-loaded heterogeneous V2O3/VN was synthesized by a facile topochemical nitridation method to increase the number of reaction sites for polysulfides [105]. It achieved a low capacity decay rate (0.1% per cycle) at a current density of 5 C. To surmount the rapid capacity decay, Zhao et al. synthesized V2O3-VN yolk-shell nanospheres in Fig. 9(e) [106], which could supply ample space to store sulfur, effectively mitigate volume fluctuations, and physically prevent the loss of polysulfides. Consequently, excellent initial discharge specific capacities (1352, 1151, 1013, 895, and 797 mA h g−1) were achieved at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C, respectively in Fig. 9(f). 5.3 Vanadium-based oxide–sulfide heterostructures Based on the MOF-templated method, a unique VO2-V3S4 heterostructure supported on layered porous carbon (VO2/V3S4@LPC) has been reported for use in sulfur cathodes [108]. The HRTEM image showed 0.58 and 0.32 nm lattice fringes corresponding to the V3S4 (200) and VO2 (011) crystal planes, respectively in Fig. 10 (a). As shown in Fig. 10(b), the VO2/V3S4@LPC/S cathode exhibited less polarization between the reduction and oxidation peaks and a stronger response current. Moreover, the peak current intensities of VO2/V3S4@LPC/S tended to increase as the cycles continued, indicating excellent electrochemical redox activity. To gain more insight into the charge transfer, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the VO2/V3S4@LPC/S cathode was studied for the first charge/discharge cycle under different potential (open circuit voltage, 1.8 and 2.8 V) in Fig. 10(c). The VO2/V3S4@LPC/S cathode exhibited a smaller interfacial and charge transfer resistance, and the presence of V3S4 nanosheets contributed to LiPSs conversion and charge-transfer capability of cathodes. The V3S4 nanosheets, which can be interpreted as a combination of conductive lamellar VS2 and a single vanadium ion, provided a multi-dimensional pathway for electron transport. The compact interconnection between exposed V3S4 nanosheets and VO2 nanoparticles offered abundant sites for the in-situ transformation of polysulfides in Fig. 10(d). VO2/V3S4 favored the reversible conversion of polysulfides. Owing to these advantages, the VO2/V3S4@LPC/S electrode showed excellent initial specific capacity (1394.6 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C) and decent cycle reversibility (0.016% decay per cycle for 100 cycles). 5.4 Other vanadium-based heterostructures VSe2 was also introduced in vanadium-based heterostructures for Li−S battery cathodes. For example, Li et al. reported a flower-like structure composed of selenium vacancy-rich VSe2- x and vanadium oxides on N-doped carbon nanosheets (NC@VO-VSe) to accelerate the bi-directional conversion of LiPSs [142]. The NC@VO-VSe was fabricated via in-situ selenization using polyaniline-V2O5 nanoflowers as the precursor. Electrochemical tests and visualization experiments demonstrated that VO-VSe heterostructures can effectively regulated the conversion of LiPSs, owing to the strong adsorption ability via the polar–polar interaction and bi-directional conversion activity of sulfur-related species. Combining vanadium-based compounds with other transition metal-based compounds to form multi-metallic heterostructures that jointly define the behavior of polysulfides is a promising direction worth exploring. For example, Wang et al. reported a compact TiO2@VN heterostructure with a high true density (5.01 g cm−3) to improve the energy density of Li−S batteries [143]. The TiO2@VN heterostructure was fabricated from natural collagen fibers via ingenious selective nitridation and served as carbon-free dual-capable catalysts for sulfur cathodes and lithium anodes in Fig. 11 (a). The fibrous structure of TiO2@VN consisted of interconnected fibrils which were formed by the accumulation of nanoparticles with a size of about 50 nm in Fig. 11(b and c). The well-defined lattice boundary in the HRTEM image demonstrated the formation of TiO2-VN heterostructures in Fig. 11(d). By combining the strong adsorption capability of TiO2 and high conductivity of VN, the TiO2-VN heterostructure created a built-in electric field at the interface to regulate charge redistribution, and accelerated anchoring-diffusion-conversion of polysulfides. The cells with TiO2@VN/S cathodes delivered an initial volumetric energy density up to 2735 Wh L–1, which was about 2.3 times that of CNT/S cathodes in Fig. 11(e). At a sulfur loading of 4.2 mg cm−2 and an electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio of 10 μL mg−1, the cell exhibited high volumetric energy density of 1696 Wh L–1 and gravimetric energy density of 997 Wh kg−1 in Fig. 11(f and g). Furthermore, the full cells assembled with TiO2@VN exhibited an excellent discharge volume energy density of 687 Wh L–1 at 0.1 C and decent cycle stability under a high sulfur loading of 3.6 mg cm−2 and lean electrolyte, suggesting high promise for practical applications. For a clear comparison, Table 3 summarizes the largest capacity and other relevant electrochemical parameters of various vanadium-based heterostructures applied as catalysts in Li−S batteries. Vanadium-based catalysts have attracted significant attention due to their ability to achieve high sulfur loadings and low E/S ratios, which are essential to realize the benefits of high energy density and promote practical applications of Li–S batteries. The PCF/VN catalysts presented an initial discharge specific capacity of 912.3 mA h g−1 at 1 C with a sulfur loading of up to 8.1 mg cm−2 [92], while VC-VO/HPC/S composite cathode exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 8.3 mA h cm−2 at 0.1 C under low electrolyte content with a sulfur loading of 9.0 mg cm−2 [141]. Button-type Li–S batteries using multibranched vanadium nitride catalysts with a sulfur loading of 6.0 mg cm−2 and a lean electrolyte volume of ∼6 μL mgs –1 delivered a high areal capacity of 5.47 mA h cm−2 and good cyclic performance over a temperature range of −20 to +60 °C [144]. 6 Conclusions and perspective In this review, recent advances in the research and development of vanadium-based oxides, nitrides, sulfides, carbides, and oxide–carbide/nitride/sulfide heterostructures as sulfur catalysts for Li–S battery cathodes have been discussed in detail. The interactions between vanadium-based compounds and polysulfides such as polar–polar interactions, Lewis acid–base interactions, and thiosulfate interactions accelerate the interconversion of sulfur-related species and effectively impede polysulfide shuttling to the anodes. Furthermore, heterostructure engineering fully utilizes the merits of each component to solve the issues and challenges of sulfur cathodes and to promote the commercialization prospects of Li–S batteries. However, some drawbacks in the current technologies must be addressed to meet the requirement of practical applications. Typically, over 25 wt% of multifunctional catalyst materials are mixed in sulfur cathodes, sacrificing the active substance loading and negatively impacting the overall energy density of the Li-S batteries. Furthermore, most catalyst materials with a high specific surface are favorable for a high sulfur loading also require a large amount of electrolyte for wetting. However, the success of Li-S batteries hinges on their ability to exceed the energy density of conventional LIBs, and to achieve this higher energy density, a lower E/S ratio is necessary [145,146]. Gupta et al. studied the relationship between the E/S ratio and energy density [147], while Yang et al. examined the same relationship with regard to cost [148]. Theoretically, a Li-S battery with an E/S ratio of 5 µL mg−1 should be capable of delivering an energy density of 500 Wh kg−1. Therefore, appropriate E/S ratios (<5 µL mg−1) must be determined for high sulfur loading. Besides, designing an intermediate layer is an effective approach to enhance sulfur loading and confine polysulfide shuttling [149]. Despite the promising performance of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures applied in Li-S battery cathodes, the complex reaction mechanisms and dynamic interactions between active phases, sulfur substances and electrolytes have not been systematically evaluated thus far. The unavoidable interactions between compounds and polysulfides in a polysulfide-rich environment result in uncontrollable effects. The positive and negative synergistic effects created in heterostructures owing to their individual components must also be thoroughly investigated. Advanced in-situ characterizations are recommended to visualize the phase evolution during redox reactions. Combined with theoretical calculations, the functioning mechanism of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures can be further elucidated, thus providing rational design principles for more suitable sulfur cathode catalysts. Vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures with low valence states are recommended to be further explored as cathode catalyst materials because vanadium with a higher valence state is more toxic. Besides, vanadium-based materials with low redox potentials are expected to be rationally designed and investigated which can restrain the formation of inactive sulfate species on the surface during repetitive oxidation of polysulfides. In conclusion, vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures with their diverse oxidation states and favorable electrochemical properties enable tailor-made solutions to meet the sulfur catalyst requirements of high-performance Li−S batteries. Further theoretical research and experimental analysis are essential to unravel the fundamental mechanism for performance enhancement, thus guiding the design of optimal vanadium-based catalysts for Li-S battery cathodes. Feasible and low-cost batch production methods are expected to be developed for the commercial use. Xinji Dong received his Master’s degree at Guangxi University under the supervision of Associate Professor Jinliang Zhu. He is working on his doctorate at Shanghai Jiao Tong University. His research focuses on cathode scaffold design for Li–S batteries. Qiao Deng received her Master’s degree from the School of Resources, Environment and Materials, Guangxi University, majoring in materials and chemical engineering. Her research interests focus on cathode materials for Li–S batteries. Fengxing Liang is studying for the Master’s degree at Guangxi University under the supervision of Associate Professor Jinliang Zhu. His research work focuses on the preparation of cathode materials for Li–S batteries and energy storage technologies. Pei Kang Shen is a Professor and Director at the Collaborative Innovation Center of Sustainable Energy Materials in Guangxi University, China. Prof. Shen received his Ph.D. degree in Chemistry at Essex University in 1992. He is the author of over 460 publications in qualified journals like Chem. Rev., Chem. Soc. Rev., J. Am. Chem. Soc., Adv. Mater., 9 specialized books, 80 patents, and more than 150 meeting presentations. His research interests include fuel cells and batteries, electrochemistry of nanomaterials and nanocomposite functional materials for different applications and electrochemical engineering. Jinliang Zhu is currently an Associate Professor at the School of Resources, Environment and Materials, Guangxi University. He received his Ph.D. degree from Sun Yat-sen University in 2014. His current research focuses on Li–S batteries and electrocatalysis. Cheng Tang received his B.E. and Ph.D. degrees from the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University in 2013 and 2018, respectively. He is currently an Associate Professor at Tsinghua University. His research focuses on developing new chemistry, materials, and devices for high-energy batteries and sustainable electrosynthesis. He was honored with the Thomson Reuters/Clarivate Analytics Highly Cited Researcher (2020–2022), MIT TR35 Asia Pacific (2021), and The Chorafas Foundation Award in Chemistry (2019).

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have attracted wide attention for their high theoretical energy density, low cost, and environmental friendliness. However, the shuttle effect of polysulfides and the insulation of active materials severely restrict the development of Li-S batteries. Constructing conductive sulfur scaffolds with catalytic conversion capability for cathodes is an efficient approach to solving above issues. Vanadium-based compounds and their heterostructures have recently emerged as functional sulfur catalysts supported on conductive scaffolds. These compounds interact with polysulfides via different mechanisms to alleviate the shuttle effect and accelerate the redox kinetics, leading to higher Coulombic efficiency and enhanced sulfur utilization. Reports on vanadium-based nanomaterials in Li-S batteries have been steadily increasing over the past several years. In this review, first, we provide an overview of the synthesis of vanadium-based compounds and heterostructures. Then, we discuss the interactions and constitutive relationships between vanadium-based catalysts and polysulfides formed at sulfur cathodes. We summarize the mechanisms that contribute to the enhancement of electrochemical performance for various types of vanadium-based catalysts, thus providing insights for the rational design of sulfur catalysts. Finally, we offer a perspective on the future directions for the research and development of vanadium-based sulfur catalysts.
